posts.name: Patrick Helman
posts.cooked:
Hello,

Our team is trying to implement a command-based framework for the first time.  We are seeing instances where the RoboRio jumps to 100% CPU and the robot “locks” to the last know state until we do an emergency stop on the DS. In the logs, we notice a lot of messages for “command loop overrun” leading up to this event.

We are looking for some advice on how to troubleshoot this issue.

Code can seen here ( main branch )

DS error logs are saved here

Log_View 1227×963 134 KB

Log_View 1227×963 134 KB

Log_View 1227×963 134 KB

Other things we’ve checked:

On the driver station, we are not seeing any error counts for the CAN metrics

Using the Rev Utility, we do see some overcurrent errors on some of the SparkMax modules.  We don’t see any CAN TX errors.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Are you able to identify what commands are running when the CPU usage is climbing vs when it’s not?

One thing that I see in your code is that you’re calling the command scheduler run method twice each loop in Robot.java. You call it in robotPeriodic, which runs in each mode, and also in teleopPeriodic and autonomousPerdiodic

posts.name: Patrick Helman
posts.cooked:
Thank you for the help.

In the last teleop session in the log, we were running a combination of driving, GrabberConveyorCmd, and ConveyorAmpCmd.

Should we only call the  command scheduler only in teleopPeriodic and autonomousPeriodic and remove it from robotPeriodic?

helmanps:

Should we only call the command scheduler only in teleopPeriodic and autonomousPeriodic and remove it from robotPeriodic?

Call it only from robotPeriodic.

Are you creating Trigger objects every loop? That’s a somewhat known issue/pitfall.

If the command scheduler is overrunning, it should also print a breakdown of how much time is taken by each command and the buttons – that should provide  helpful info as to what precisely is taking up a lot of time.

Yep, like I thought: Here you’re creating a Trigger every loop. There’s a known bug there that leads to loop overruns.

Create the trigger once, and pass it as a BooleanSupplier (Triggers are BooleanSuppliers):

If there are more similar use sites in your code, do the same with them as well.

posts.name: Patrick Helman
posts.cooked:
Thank you so much @Starlight220 !

We implemented your suggested changes and are now warning and error free.
